segments.text: This is an interview with Mr. Aubrey Grice by Stuart Dunn on April 16, 1989 at the home of Mr. Grice concerning the dropping of the bomb on Hiroshima.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Mr. Grice, is this okay with you?
Yes.
Thank you.
Mr. Grice, when were you born?
December 13, 1923.
That's not that long ago.
65 years.
What was your educational background?
Well, in the beginning, I grew up on a farm in East Texas.
I went to a little two-room schoolhouse through the eighth grade.
Then I rode a school bus into a little town in Winsboro, about eight miles away.
and completed high school there, graduated in 1940, just after I turned 16.
So we had 11 grades then instead of 12.
And then for the next few years I worked in Dallas and got my father on the farm until World War II came along, and then I started some of my other education during and after that.
Was it a college education?
Yeah, after the war.
I got out in 1946 and went to Southern Methodist University here in Dallas, and was graduated in August 1948.
Okay.
Brother Grice, when did you get into the service?
In April 1943.
April of 1943.
And why did you join the service?

Well, you know, the Japanese had attacked Pearl Harbor in 1941, and everybody was going in that time, and I would have been drafted, I was, in 1943, I was 19, and I was at the age, they had just, when they first started drafting people into the war, they was 21.
And then after a while, or a little bit after Pearl Harbor, I think there, I can't remember the exact time, but they lowered it to 18.
And so I knew that I was going to be drafted and have to go into service, and I always wanted to fly.
Little guy down on the farm, I'd stop and watch airplanes fly over.
Whatever I was doing.
Yeah, and I just was fascinated by airplanes, and so I wanted to fly, and so I had an opportunity to
volunteer to get into the Army Air Corps at that time.
Later became the US Air Force.
And so I went in and took all my examinations and everything and passed and got in.
Super.
As a cadet.
That's super.
How did you go about joining?
Well, I talked to my folks and of course I was, at that time the legal age was 21.
instead of 18.
And so I had to have their permission.
But I talked to them, and they said, well, if that's what you want to do, that's fine.
You're going to have to go in anyhow.
You're going to be drafted at some point.
You may as well do what you want to do.
So they were very cooperative.
And I believe we went to Tyler about 50 miles away to a recruitment office and talked with the Air Force down there and my father and me.
And I came back, and I took some tests.
No, they sent me to Greenville, up to Greenville, Texas, to have a physical.
And so between all the tests, both the physical tests and the health tests and the whole thing, I was accepted.
It was really pretty simple then.
What were your duties while you were in the service?
First thing I did after I got into the service, we were sent up to Wichita Falls, Texas as an induction center.
We were supposed to be there and have some very tough basic training for about 12 weeks.
And after I was there about three weeks, they sent a bunch of us up to Stillwater, Oklahoma at that time.
And that's when we really started cadets.
We were enrolled in school there at Oklahoma State, that time Oklahoma A&M.
Right.
And we were there for about three and a half months.
And mostly we were studying things like history, physics.
We got to fly in little Piper Cubs for about, I think we had about six hours at that point.
First time I had ever been in an airplane.
Was in a piper club?
Was in a piper club.
How did you like that?
Oh, loved it.
I thought this was the greatest thing ever.
That's one of my friends has one of those.
That's great.
So would you want me to kind of continue with through like this then?
Yeah.
For a while?
So we were there for three and a half months.
Most of that was studying and some basic training and some, particularly physical training.
We had some, they had the Oklahoma A&M program.
football coach squad that gave us our physical education.
And by the time we left there, we could run a five mile cross country at a very good pace and not be panting very much really.
We really were in good shape, tremendous shape.
And then we were, after we completed that, we went to San Antonio to
We were, for several weeks, we were just in batteries of tests every day.
More physical education and things like that.
And a few classes, films and so forth, to teach us about different things, but mostly just for classification purposes.
And that's where, through tests and different things, it was determined whether you would be eligible for pilot school,
or a navigation school or a bombardier school.
So I fortunately, I was able to continue on with my ambition of being a pilot and completed that.
And then from there we were transferred to Santa Ana, California, where we had what's called pre-flight.
Again, more studies, more physical education, more drilling,
Discipline.
Learning a lot of discipline.
So we went through that and then from there I went up to Merced, California for primary training.
And we flew Stearman's.
I don't know if you know what a Stearman is.
I know exactly what a Stearman is.
Bi-wing, open cockpit, two seats in each wing.
That was a riot.
That was more fun.
have fun with it, and do everything with it.
And everyone's ambition was, we wore helmets and goggles.
You looked like World War I pilots.
And the airplane was almost World War I vintage.
But you couldn't wear a scarf until you had solo.
And then you could wear a white scarf.
And we, once we soloed, we had a, we were, we all had and wore a white silk scarf about eight feet long.
And it would trail out to the air.
It was great fun.
That was just fun in that flying school.
It was just really fun.
We were really on our toes and had to be very careful.
It was an airplane that was actually difficult to fly and that was one reason we flew it.
It would wing ground very easily and flip over on it's nose because the top wing held the gasoline.
If you were full of gas it was a little bit tight if you slammed on it.
And if you run into problems, you were in trouble.
They came after you.
Yeah.
That was funny.
How did you get into the B-29?
Well, it's a little bit of evolution.
Went from there, then up to, from Santa Brea to Merced, California.
Flew in basic training, flew a BT-13, basic trainer single engine, in that area.
From that point,
All the way through, I had requested to be a fighter pilot.
Of course.
If not a fighter pilot, then a twin-engine attack aircraft.
And my last choice was to fly a four-engine bomber.
When this was, I graduated in the class of 44G, so I graduated from cadet school in August of 1944.
It was getting late in the war.
And the war in Europe was essentially winding down.
And they just basically, the comment was, we really don't need any more fighter pilots.
We got all we need.
Every person in my class, everyone, was sent to Twin Engine Advanced School.
So we came from Merced, California to Pecos, Texas.
to fly a twin engine advanced trainer.
So we all got training in an advanced trainer.
We pretty well knew that that would put us into a bomber of some sort.
So I graduated from cadet school in August the 4th, 1944.
And came home for the first time in 15 months.
Got married to my high school sweetheart.
The American story, it seems like.
Joe Irby.
And we had a good time.
We enjoyed it.
I was immediately assigned to a B-17 school in Hobbs, New Mexico.
And we went out there, and she went with me.
And by this time, of course, being an officer, we could take our wives.
we found a place to live off base that we could afford.
And so we enjoyed the three and a half months there.
It was just great.
From there we went to Lincoln, Nebraska to determine where we would go.
Usually either a B-17 group would go someplace and form a crew and fly, a combat crew, fly with them a little while
and get acquainted with each other and then go overseas.
The war was further winding down by this point.
About half of the group went on through into B-17s and went into Europe.
Some of them even got overseas.
The war just wound up.
They had more pilots than needed and they just didn't remember.
They selected a large group, about half of them, to go into B-29.
aircraft, a new, relatively new aircraft at that time, flying into the Pacific.
And this was kind of fun because we had to go through another three and a half months of training.
And they sent us down to Clovis, New Mexico, to a big airfield down here for this training.
We had been there just about a month into this training, and they selected three special crews

or formed three special crews out of this entire group that they wanted to become photo reconnaissance pilots and crews to do mapping of Japan and the Pacific for the invasion of Japan and to do photographic work for the 20th Air Force.
So I was selected fortunately to be among that group and we spent several months learning a lot about photography
piloting, exactness in flying, discipline in flying, all the things that are necessary to really be a disciplined, good photographic crew for the 20th Air Force.
So your main duty then was reconnaissance, I guess.
Yes.
What were some of your most memorable experiences while you were flying?
Oh, if we go back to cadet area, part of it, that was a lot of fun in the little things.
My first instructor in primary school was an older fellow who was, at that time he was older, he was probably in his late 30s,
He had flown the Mayo in an open cockpit aircraft for the Army.
That tells you how old he was, almost immediately after World War I.
And he was a real fly by the seat of your pants type guy.
But he was a great pilot, a really good pilot.
He really taught us a lot.
I think we were able to go through cadet school
largely on the basis of what that man taught us in a way of discipline and just how do you fly an airplane.
There's a lot of things that go with that.
And I remember he had two cadets.
He was one of the leaders.
A man and a guy named Griffin, Red Griffin, red-headed guy from Georgia.
And Bud Grice from Dallas.
We were his two cadets.
He came in one day and he said,
motioned both of us to come over to the aircraft and he stood there and he looked at both of us and he said, you know, I want to tell you all a story.
He told us a story about two cadets he had one time.
He said one of them was real sharp but wasn't disciplined and didn't have the feel.
And the other one was just a poor old guy that could hardly speak the English language.
But he had a feel for
airplanes, and he listened and paid good attention.
He said, the guy, this dumb old guy, he said, he just, he was a fantastic pilot.
The other guy that was a real brain, he just never did really learn to fly.
And he said, it just goes to show you, the dumber they are, the better you can fly.
He turned around and walked away about 10 feet, stopped, turned around and looked at us, and he said, you two guys ought to make damn good pilots.
So I remember him with a lot of chuckles, but I also remember him for being a great pilot and a great teacher.
And he was that.
And a lot of other experiences.
I guess one of my most fun experiences in B-29, as photo reconnaissance groups, we didn't carry bombs.
All of our bomb bays were stripped out and our bomb bays were filled with gas tanks.
And we could fly probably 22 or 23 hours on non-stop missions.
The longest mission I had was 21 hours and 55 minutes.
And it was at the beginning of that particular mission because we were loaded with gas.
All we could get on board.

We needed to be up to Japan about 9 o'clock in the morning because the shadows were right to take pictures and we could, the pictures could be, you could tell more about the pictures and what they meant.
Right.
Height of buildings and different things.
And so we were going to leave Guam that night at 1.30.
Most of our flights we took off at night, got up there in the daytime.
So it was 1,700 miles from there to Tokyo.
And B-29s and crews were about 250, something like that.
Used a little bit more power, didn't need to save fuel.
We could, 275.
But it wasn't, then it was a fast air crane, but not today.
But we were loaded and our stall speed was, as I recall, was about 135.
And I remember we were on an 8,000-foot runway when we took off that night.
The moon was shining, and we gave it the gun with all we had.
We got right on the end of the runway and held the brakes until we revved up the props full speed and then released the brakes so we could get all we could go.
And at the end of the paved runway, they had bulldozed the coral back for probably half a mile.
And then there was about a 50 foot rise over a little, actually a little mountain type thing.
And then about a 250 foot drop to the water just to straighten out the cliff.
And when we went off the end of the runway, we were still doing about 130.
There was no way we could stop.
And we didn't want to hit that cliff out there with about 10,000 gallons of fuel.
And so we just hit emergency power.
gave it all she had, and we still had some coral.
And I had the co-pilot and said, you read off the speed.
And as soon as our speed hit about 137, just two miles above that, I just started pulling back on the stick.
And I just, I didn't look at anything except the airspeed indicator.
And if it looked like it was going to drop, I dropped the nose.
And I just hoped we were going to climb enough to get over the cliff.
And we were sitting there and the plane was so close to the stall speed until you could feel it shake.
It wasn't really stable in the air.
It needed to be more than two or three miles above the stall speed to be stable.
But then just what seemed like hours almost was obviously a minute or a minute and a half.
I can see the reflection of the moon in the water.
And I just shoved the nose down.
And we picked up speed and pulled it on out.
Climbed up a little bit, put it on autopilot, and then just felt my blood turn to ice water.
But it didn't turn to ice water prior to that because you can't.
Too busy.
Too many things going on out there to get scared.
But it was a little bit frightening.
Could you please describe your experience and what you saw on the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima?
Okay.
Our crew, again, took off from Guam around 2 o'clock in the morning and arrived over the coast of Japan probably 8 o'clock or so.
Three crews had been selected to go up on the special mission.
We were designated to go to Hiroshima.
Another crew was sent to another area, and another one to another, and I'm not quite sure.
They had the primary target, a secondary, and a third alternate.
In case of weather or something, if one didn't work out, they'd go to another.
We did not know what we were going to photograph.
We were told where to be, be above 30,000 feet, to circle Hiroshima within a radius of about 10 miles, no closer than 10, and stay fairly close to 10.
Keep all cameras on board, of which we had coverage
every angle on the aircraft except the 45 degree coming up.
And we had every camera going and taking a picture every five seconds or several hours.

And so we were to be there, arrive at that time, certain time, and just start circling and observe everything that happened, be sure the cameras were operating appropriately, keep them full of film, just keep everything going.
watch what's going on and take a lot of pictures.
That was our instructions.
So we arrived at our target Hiroshima was just off the nose and we turned to the right so I turned to the right so I could circle and Hiroshima would be on my left because I was in the pilot seat.
And we began our circle and before we had just after we had started
to circling.
One of the gunners called out B-29 approaching on the right.
And we all looked and we saw a B-29.
As he came across in front of our nose just a little above us, we could read the marking on the tail and we knew that the aircraft was from the 20th Air Force
And we knew it had either come from Guam or Saipan or Tinian, one of the three fields.
So we watched it come across.
It kind of came over in front of us across Hiroshima.
And then just about the time it crossed Hiroshima, he really dropped his nose.
Just really a steep dive.
And just moved way on out and turned off to the left a little bit.
And we just observed this, and one of the gunners just remarked, said, well, let him go.
You know, we hadn't seen anything and had no idea why he was doing this.
And we were observing him, like, you know, why did he dive out so quickly?
And about this time, then, just this brilliant flash.
It was a sunny and bright day.
on the one hand and yet this brilliant flash just out there in Hiroshima.
And it just covered that area and then of course this huge orange ball first covered the city and then you could see debris and this cloud of smoke going up.
And we were at 33,000 feet and it took less than three minutes for that column of smoke to reach our altitude.
which would give you some idea of the amount of heat in it because it was rising because of the heat.
And so we, you know, there were comments like, you know, look at that, what was that, you know, what in the world, you know, like this.
And we knew that this aircraft had done something, obviously, but of course none of us had ever heard of an atomic bomb.
And we hadn't been instructed or anything on what was happening.
And we speculated that, boy, he must have hit a huge ammunition dump.
And someone said, well, yeah, but there must have been a lot of fuel too because all that smoke and everything, and you can see the fires burning and everything.
But I mean, it looked just like total chaos, you know, on the ground.
And then this smoke coming in.
So, you know, for the next 10 to 15 minutes, all kinds of speculation about the crew and all those, wondering what in the world had taken place here.
So we continued to circle for, I would guess, about another two hours.
And then, after that time, we had been instructed to fly over a few miles, but not too far, and begin mapping.
And we would just fly over to a place
go down and fly back across and back over, just making an aerial map of the entire Japan.
We had a lot of missions that included that.

We'd go up and do special things, whatever they needed, and then said, okay, after you finish that, go over and you start at this point, start mapping, and back and forth, just map, map, taking pictures, and, you know, preparation for an invasion,
And so we did that, and even during this time, we had our cameras on board, and we were still getting pictures off in the distance, probably 30, 40 miles away of this Columbus home.
And so we did this until, you know, mid-afternoon, gas and fuel were in the position where it was time to go home.
So we headed back for our 1700 mile.
slow descent from there to Guam.
How long were you in the air total?
We left about 2 o'clock in the morning and arrived back at Guam I believe around 9 o'clock in the evening.
That's a lot of hours.
What did you feel, what were your thoughts after you heard President Truman get on the
and get on the radio and describe what had just happened?

Well, we had, as we came in that evening, we, as always, our crews were met by intelligence officers from 20th Air Force Headquarters, just to talk to us a few minutes, see if we observed anything, if there was any kind of anti-aircraft or fighter aircraft or anything.
Anything we observed, either there or on the ground, troop movements, anything, they always wanted to know about it because all little bits of information made sense and things.

And so they interrogated the crew for a few minutes and then we were dismissed and went on with our buddies and spent a couple of hours in the evening, had a nice dinner, talked with them for a while.
So we were telling everybody about what we'd seen and what had happened and what speculation it was.
We said, well, why don't we call the 20th Air Force Headquarters and find out what they hit.
And everybody said, well, it's kind of late, we'll do that in the morning.
So we all went off to bed.
Well, after a mission like that, we were allowed to just sleep in the next day.
If you wanted to get up at noon or 6 p.m., you could do it.
Because you were really worn out and tired.
After 18 or 20 hours in an aircraft, you're tired.
Some of my buddies came over and woke me up and said, hey, President's on the radio.
come listen to this.
He's going to explain what you saw yesterday."
And so I jumped up.
I was interested and I went, well this must be something else for the President to explain it, you know.
So we listened then and we heard the President explain about this dropping of the first atomic bomb and what it was.
And that's the first thing that we realized and recognized what this was.
And we talked about it and really
they explained about the damage it had done and the number of people that had been killed.
And they explained about, particularly about the fact that they had explained this to Japan and what it was and asked them to surrender.
And just gave them a certain length of time to surrender.
And this brought great joy to us.
Everyone
on the island of Guam.
I happened to have a nephew who was a doctor at that time.
He was on, he was in the Navy.
He was on detached service with the 6th Marine Corps Division on Guam.
And they were, had been pulled back from Okinawa and were resting there recuperating, training and preparing to invade Japan.
And they dreaded it.
They knew how fanatic the Japanese were and they dreaded it.
They knew
that perhaps most of them would not return.
And so we had often met and sat and talked about that, about this invasion.
And we were going to play a big part in it.
Of course, we'd be up above taking pictures and doing things of this nature.
On the one hand, on the other hand, we expected everything they had to be thrown against us, anti-aircraft guns,
fighter aircraft, everything.
Even suicidal missions to fly, just fly them into aircraft.
So no one looked forward to that.
So here, all of a sudden, when something came just, you know, out of the clear blue to us that could potentially end the war any day now, we were elated.
I'm going to be very honest with you.
We were elated.
And at that time,
And I guess I would have to say that was my feeling at that point.
We were elated.
What about, what were your feelings when we dropped the second one on Nagasaki?
Well we had waited these few days to try to see, hoping Japan would surrender and end the war.
And they didn't.
And so the second one was sent over and dropped at Nagasaki.
Nagasaki.
Nagasaki.
And we just said, well, hopefully this will do it.
And I guess that was our feelings then.
I don't think anyone relished the killing of that many people on the one hand.
But if you look at it from our standpoint, where probably a million or more men would be invading Japan,
and probably half of them or more may never come back, of our own people.
Plus, what that would do, not just to their soldiers, but their women and their children.
And, you know, there would have been hundreds of thousands of people killed in that invasion.
Those two bombs killed, what, 200,000 people on that range?

And so if you look at it from that standpoint, there were many less deaths from those two bombs that ended the war and brought peace than there would have been had we been required or necessary to invade China and end it that way.
And so looking at it to that point, from our standpoint, our feelings, it was a great blessing, as bad as it was.
Overall, it was a great blessing.
And if you really look at it realistically, there's just no denying that.
It saved many, many lives.
I guess then, in your opinion, we should have dropped the bomb then for the purpose of stopping the war.
for the purpose of stopping the war.
They took two of them.
The first one just didn't do it.
I guess they were so stunned by it, it takes a while for something like that to soak in, I think.
Just, you know, how powerful this is, what it can do.
And very shortly after the second one was dropped, of course they did surrender.
Total, unconditional surrender.
We put them back on their feet again, and they've done very well since.
Yes.
Very, very well.

And in September of 1965, a writer for the New York Times by the name of William L. Lawrence, who actually was in the bomb, or the plane that carried the bomb to Nagasaki, he was writing in regards to...
to that bombing.
And one of his quotes, it says, does one feel pity or compassion for the poor devils about to die?
Not when one thinks of Pearl Harbor or the death march on Bataan.
Were these sentiments kind of the feeling of everybody out there?
Or, you know, if so, explain.
Do people really believe that?
Yeah, I think so.
You know, here,
I was a 19 year old guy through my training.
I was a 20 year old when I experienced this.
I'd had a lot of experiences in life and gained a lot of maturity over, because of the circumstances at the time.
But I was young.
And really, we had been taught all the way through cadet school and films and everything.
to, I mean, basically to hate the Japanese.
Because of Pearl Harbor, because of the way they fought, because of the way they treated our prisoners.
You were just almost taught that they were just not human beings.
In a sense.
That, you know, to wipe them off the face of the earth would be good rhythm, so to speak.
It was almost like that.
And I'm saying this on a hindsight basis, but we were, we were really
Well, they were the enemy.
It was destroy them before they destroy you type situation.
Self-defense.
You get them, they get you.
Be alert.
Don't be tricked.
In fact, we were very explicitly told, if you get shot down, if it's at all possible, don't bail out because you probably will never reach the ground.
And history taught us this.
They'd shoot you in a parachute.
Or if they captured you, they might just cut your head off.
You may or may not be in prison.
If you did get in prison, it would be horrible.
If possible, glide out or anything you can do and ditch in the ocean or bail out over the ocean or whatever.
But if you can get away from the coast, do so.
Even if you can land in Tokyo Harbor.
And we had, it wasn't known outside to us and a few other people at the time, we had submarines in Tokyo Bay that would pick up pilots and bring them back home.
And air crew people and a lot were saved.
They would get out away from the land and the submarine would stick the periscope up, you could throw a rope over and they'd just tow you out.
until dark or it was far enough away and they'd done it around the surface, bring you on board and gone.
So we were taught about this, we were trained like this.
We didn't think much about the poor devils down there.
After what they did to Pearl Harbor and stuff like that.
That wasn't in our makeup at that time, it wasn't in our training.
We were not taught compassion.
Not during the war?
Not at that time.
I just read that statement, and I just found it kind of interesting that he wrote that, because it really kind of hit me.
Something that I thought a lot of people would kind of feel the same, or I didn't know if anybody felt different.
Well, you know, today, in the light of day, you think about it, and obviously you would have compassion about one person who is about to die, let alone
If you actually knew, I'm going to drop this bomb and 100,000 is going to die.
Even in times like that, I suppose, if you really knew exactly what you were about to do and the circumstances there, I'm sure you'd have some compassionate thoughts about it.
You'd know that some of those were soldiers and things that you were taught to kill, but you'd also know that there were a lot of mothers, a lot of children, a lot of babies,
Many things.
I don't think you could help but think of your mother, your sisters, your little brothers, your nieces and nephews.
I think you'd shake your head.
You'd go ahead and do your duty.
But you would have some compassion.
Definitely so.
How do you feel
about atomic weapons now and the way they've developed?
I think they've been overdeveloped to a large extent.
I believe, you know, Stuart, it's extremely important and maybe this is the will of the Lord that the United States develop this weapon first.
We used it twice
to end war, a very great and bloody war.
The bloodiest part was still to come, and we avoided that by the use of these two bombs.
It's my opinion that our possession of that bomb has kept the peace over these years.
I fully believe that.
I think there are forces on this earth, have been, and still even today,
that would love to conquer the United States of America and have a different form of government here.
Totalitarian, communist, both of which are totalitarian, or whatever.
We're a free nation.
We're the envy of everyone.
And we have the freedom that people envy and enjoy.
And they would like to take that away from us.
I believe the atomic bomb, its possession, by our country has protected us from no telling what.
There have been wars, but they have been limited wars.
They've been smaller wars, so to speak.
Simply because they were afraid to expand it to the point to where we or anyone else would use the atomic bomb.
And so
Because of that, I think it has been a great deterrent.
We and all of us have too much of it now.
The only fear I have, I don't particularly fear us having it, I don't fear Russia having it.
Because it's a standoff.
And neither one of us will take that step.
My great fear right now would be some lunatic type individual, the head of a government, or
of a terrorist organization that would somehow acquire one of these and use it for blackmail or for the great destruction it can cause.
And there are people of that mindset around them, unfortunately, but they are.
